That ſhe would cheat ſo honeſt a Gentleman,
That came a Suiter to her for pure love.

sp.speaker: Scra.
sp.l: Love? miſchief of love.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: Alas, I know
It was not her Eſtate that you ſought after,
Your love was honeſter; and then that after,
Should cozen you?

sp.speaker: Scra.
sp.l: She ſhall not cozen me.
I'll have my Horſe-Litter made ready ſtraight,
And leave her houſe.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: But when you ſee her Sir,
It may be your affection will return.
If you ſhould leave her onely upon this,
The world would think that you were covetous;
And covetouſneſs is ſuch a ſin you know.

sp.speaker: Scra.
sp.l: You do not mock me, do you?

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: Who, I Sir?
I know your Worſhip do's abhor the ſin
Of covetouſneſs; But I confeſs indeed
'Twould vexe a man to have been cozoned ſo.

sp.speaker: Sir Arg.
sp.l: Havel liv'd all this while to be o' reach'd
And cheated by a woman? I'll fotſake her
Immediately.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis a happy thing
When men can love with ſuch diſcretion,
As to forſake, when they ſhall ſee juſt cauſe.
Some are ſo fond in their affections,
That though provok'd by all the injuries
That can be off'red, they can never leave
The Miſtriſs of their Hearts.

sp.speaker: Sir Arg.
sp.l: I warrant her
For any ſuch affection in old Argent.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: I do believe it Sir, you are too wiſe.

sp.speaker: Lad. Cov.
sp.l: How do you Sir?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: E'ene as I may.
You do not mean I ſhall be e're the better
For you.

sp.speaker: Lad. Cov.
sp.l: How's this? I do not underſtand
What you ſhould mean

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: You may, if you conſider:
But if you do not, I'll explain it to you.
Have I deſerv'd ſuch dealing at your hands?

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: As what?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: As that you ſhould ſpeak one thing to me,
And mean another; But I'll make it plainer;
You ſeem'd to love me, and for love it ſeems,
Thinking to marry me, have made away
All you Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Nay 'tis too true?
Or elſe your Chaplain do's you wrong.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Oh Villain!

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Nay Villain him no Villains; is it ſo
Or not?

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: If ſhe deny it to you Sir,
I can produce her hand, and have the Deed.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: On monſtrous villainy! Oh impudence!
Can'ſt thou abuſe me thus, that firſt of all
Did'st counſel me to do it?

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: I confeſs
I gave you way, and for the time did wink
At your falſe dealing; but at laſt my conſcience
Would not permit me to conceal it longer.
I have diſcharg'd it now, and told the truth.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: 'Twas well none of you, Sir; well, I'll away.
Madam, ſeek out ſome other m • n to ch • at,
For me you ſhall not.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Stay Sir, my Eſtate
Shall ſtill be good; the Feoffees will be honeſt.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: I, that they will, to keep what is their own.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Oh monſtrous wickedneſs! was e're 〈◊〉 like
Heard of before?

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: I know the Feoffee mindes.

div.stage: Enter Freeman, Euphues, Barnet, Dotterel, Whimſey.

sp.speaker: Free
sp.l: How fare you Madam? Wherefore look you ſadly
At ſuch a joyful time?

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Oh Mr. Freeman
I am undone, and ruin'd.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: No, good Madam,
We'll ſee you ſhall not want.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: You ſhall have a fair competence allow'd you.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: What riddle have we here?

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Our thou ungratious
Diſſembling villain.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: An indifferent means
Will keep your Ladyſhip; for you are paſt
Thoſe vanities which younger Ladies uſe;
You need no gaudy clothes, no change of Faſhions,
No Paintings nor Perfumes.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I would fain know
The bottom of this.

sp.speaker: La. Whi
sp.l: Servant, can you diſcover
What this ſhould mean?

sp.speaker: Dott
sp.l: No Miſtriſs, I proteſt,
With all the wit I have

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: And for you Houſe,
You ſhall have leave to ſtay here, till we have
Provided for you.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Oh my heart will break!

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Here is the fineſt turn that e're I ſaw

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: I will reſolve you Gentlemen; This Lady
To cozen me in marriage, had it ſeems
Paſt her Eſtate away; into what hands
'Tis fall'n I know not, nor I care not, I.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: 'Tis fall'n into the hands of wiſe men, Sir,
That know how to make uſe of what is theirs.

sp.speaker: Cov
sp.l: This hypocrite perſwaded me to do't,
And then diſcover'd all, as if one purpoſe
He ſought my ruine.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: No not I, good Madam;
'Twas for your ſoules health; I have done you good,
And eas'd you of a burden, and a great one
So much Eſtate would have been ſtill a cauſe
Of cares unto you; and thoſe cares have hinder'd
Your quiet paſſage to a better life.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Excellent divel! how I love him now.
Never did knavery play a juſter part.

sp.speaker: Fru.
sp.l: And why ſhould you at ſuch an age as this
Dreame of marriage, a thing ſo farre
Unfit, nay moſt unnatural, and prophane,
To ſtain that holy ordinance, and make it
But a meere bargain? for two clods of earth
Might have been join'd as well in matrimony.
'Tis for your ſoules health, Madam, I do this.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: How much was I miſtaken in this Chaplaine?
I ſee h' has braines.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Though 't be diſhoneſty
In him, yet juſtly was it plac'd on her!
And I could even applaud it.

sp.speaker: Lad. Whim.
sp.l: I proteſt,
I love this Chaplain.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.l: So do I, ſweet Miſtris,
Or I am an errant foole.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: But yet I hope,
The feoffees may prove honeſt; Ile try them.

sp.speaker: Fru.
sp.l: Ile goe and bring them to your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Ile ſtay no longer; make my Litter ready.
Lady farewel; and to you all.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Nay, Sir,
Then let me interpoſe; let me entreat you
By all the rites of neighbourhood, Sir Argent,
Make not ſo ſuddain a departure now.
What though the buſineſſe have gone ſo croſſe?
You may part fairly yet. Stay till to morrow:
Let not the country take too great a notice
Of theſe proceedings and ſtrange breach; 't will be
Nothing but a diſhonour to you both.
Pray Sir, conſent; give me your hand, Sir Argent.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: At your entreaty,

sp.speaker: Sir,
sp.l: Ile ſtay till morning.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Before that time you may conſider better.

div.head: Actus Quintus.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: I'Ll not refuſe my Uncles courteſie,
But go and ſee his Houſe; I ſhould before
Have done that duty to him, but I thought
My viſits were not welcom, ſince he liv'd
So cloſe and privately.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Sweet Coz', you'll finde
A happy alteration in my Father,
And that there dwel a kinde and honeſt ſoul
Within his breſt; though wretched Avarice
The uſual fault of age, have heretofore
Too much kept back the good expreſſions
Of ſuch like thoughts, he now will make a mends
To all the world, and has begun already
With his poor Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Cozen, I ſhall be
Too bad a Gueſt at this ſad time, and bring
Nothing but ſorrow to my Uncles houſe.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: You'll be your ſelfe a welcom Gueſt to him;
And I ſhall think our roof exceeding happy
If it may mitigate that killing grief
Which your ſo ſolitary life too much
Has nouriſh'd in you Cozen, feed it not;
'Tis a diſeaſe that will in time conſume you.
I have already giv'n the beſt advice
That my poor knowledge will afford, to eaſe
Your troubled thoughts If time which heaven allows
To cure all grief, ſhould not have power to do it;
If death of Father, Mother, Husband, Wife,
Should be lamented ſtill, the world would wear
Nothing but black. Sorrow alone would reign
In every Family that lives, and bring
Upon poor Mortals a perpetual night.
You muſt Forget it, Cozen.

sp.speaker: Mat
sp.l: Never can I
Forget my love to him.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Nor do I ſtrive
To teach you to forget that love you bear
To his dear memory, but that grief which lies
Wrapt in amongſt it, and turns all to Poyſon;
Making it mortal to that ſoul that taſtes it.
'Tis that, ſweet Cozen, which I hope that time
May by degrees extinguiſh. Will you pleaſe
To walk along? my Father long ere this
Expects us I am ſure, and longs to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I blame you not at all, that by the Law
And vertue of your places, are requir'd
To apprehend me.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: We are ſorry, Sir,
We were inforc'd to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: But I wonder
What curious eye it was that ſearch'd ſo far
Into my ſecret walks, that did diſcover
This dark abode of mine, and envy'd me
My ſolitary ſorrow; ſuch a life
As I enjoy'd, a man might well afford
To his moſt great and mortal Enemy.

sp.speaker: Offi
sp.l: 'Twas a plain fellow, Sir, tha brought us hither,
In the Kings name, and left us when we had you.
But Sir, we wiſh you all the good we may

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I thank you Friends; I cannot tell at all
Whom to ſuſpect, nor will I further vex
My thoughts in ſearch of ſuch a needleſs thing.
I call to minde what once my Theodore
Told me by way of a ſurmiſe, but ſure
It cannot be ſo foul; ſhall I entreat you
To carry me to old Sir Argent Scrape
My Kiſman? I would onely ſpeak with him
Before I go to priſon; And let one,
If you can ſpare a man, go run for me
To Mr. Earthworm's houſe, and bid his ſon
Meet me with old Sir Argent; he lies now
At my Lady

sp.speaker: Covets
sp.l: houſe: I have about me
What will reward your pains, and highly too.

sp.speaker: Offi.
sp.l: It ſhall be done as would have it, Sir,

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I dare not ſend to fair Artemia:
The ſight of her, and of ſo dear a ſorrow
As ſhe would ſhew, would but afflict me more.
Perchance I may come ſafely off; till then
I would conceal this accident from her.
But Fame is ſwifteſt ſtill when ſhe goes laden
With news of miſchief. She too ſoon will hear,
And in her ſorrow I ſhall doubly ſuffer.
Thus are we Fortunes paſtimes, one day live
Advanc'd to Heaven by the peoples breath,
'The next hurl'd down into th' Abyſs of death.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: But are you ſure 'tis hereabouts he lives?
Ha! who is that? 'tis he, and in the hands
Of Officers; Cozen, the miſchief's done
Before we come.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: O my dear Eugeny!

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Artemia too? Ay me! ſhe ſwoons: help, help!
Look up, my Love; there is no fear at all
For me; no danger, all is ſafe, and full
Of hope and comfort.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: She begins to come
Unto her ſelf again.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: But pray Sir, tell,
How came you hither, Noble Euphues?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I never knew the place; but now by her
Inſtructions found it out: I came to bear
Her company; and her intent of comming
Was to inform you of a danger neer,
Of ſuch a monſtrous miſchief, as perchance
You ſcarce can credit; old Sir Argent Scrape
By me, and by another Gentleman,
Was overheard to ſay, • hat he had Scouts,
And had laid certain plots to apprehend
His Kinſman Eugeny juſt before th' Aſſizes,
Beſides what further means he did intend
Cloſely to work your death, he then declar'd
To the old covetous Lady, whom he came
A Suiter to.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Prophetick Theodore,
How right thou wert!

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: This thing when I had heard,
I told it her; and we with ſpeed made hither,
But ere we came, the miſchief was fulfil'd.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I thank you, Sir, for this diſcovery:
How ere I ſpeed, pray pardon me, if I
Shall by the Hand of Juſtice, die your Debtor.
How ſoon from Vertue, and an honoured Spirit,
Man may receive what he can never merit!
Be not thou cruel, may Artemia;
Do not torment me with thy grief, and make
Me die before my time; let hope a while
Suſpend thy ſorrow; if the worſt ſhould fall,
Thy ſorrow would but more enfeeble me,
And make me ſuffer faintly for thy ſake.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: If worſt ſhould fall, my Love (which Heaven foreſend)
How could I chuſe but ſuffer?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I will hope
Your ſafety yet may well be wrought, and knowing
Sir Argent's minde, you know what wayes to truſt.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Good Cozen help us with thy counſel now,
If thou do'ſt love my life.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Fear it not Coz';
If I may aide you, Sir, in any thing,
You ſhall command it.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Sir, I cannot thank you
So much as it deſerves; this timely favour,
If not in life, yet ſhall at leaſt in death
Endeare me to you.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Do not name that word,
My deareſt love.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You muſt be ſpeedy, Sir,
In all your courſes now.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Then let me begge
That you would meet me at my Lady Covets.
Ile ring Sir Argent Scrape ſo loud a peale,
As ſhall perchance awake his bedder'd ſoule,
Aud rowze it, though ſo deepely ſunke in droſſe,
Drown'd and orewhelm'd with mucke. Goe you together,
And leave me to my way.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: Farewel deare love.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis ſure; I know your Ladyſhip
Is ſo poſſeſt.

sp.speaker: La. Whim
sp.l: I think he loves me well,
And will not now ſtart backe from marrying me.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: That is the happy hour he only longs for.
But if ſo ſtrange a thing ſhould come to paſſe,
(Which yet I think impoſſible) that this
Your marriage ſhould break off; I will give backe
Into your hand this bond which I receiv'd;
And 'tis worth nothing, Madam, as you know
By the condition.

sp.speaker: La. Whim
sp.l: True, I fear it not;
But I durſt you if 'twere otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: He waits the hour when you will pleaſe to ty
The happy knot with him.

sp.speaker: La. Whim.
sp.l: He ſhall no longer
Waite for it now; Ile goe confirme him.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: But think not, Gentle-Madam, that I ſharke,
O • cheat him in it; I have to a ſum
Greater then this from him as good a title
As right can give; though my unhappy fortunes
Made me forbeare the tryal of my title
Whiles his old crafty father was alive;
He held from me a farme of greater value,
As all the Neighbours know; I then forbore it,
And will do ſtill, ſince by an eaſyer way
I may have ſatisfaction. But here comes
One that has loſt a marriage.

sp.speaker: La Cov.
sp.l: Tell me, Truſty,
What ſay the feoffees?

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: They'll ſay nothing, Madam,
Make me no anſwer, but that they know how
To manage their own fortunes.

sp.speaker: La. Cov.
sp.l: All the world
Conſpires againſt me; I am quite undone.

sp.speaker: Tru.
sp.l: I promiſe you truly, Madam, I believe
They meane little better then plain knavery.

sp.speaker: La. Cov.
sp.l: I, 'tis too true.

sp.speaker: La. Whim.
sp.l: How does your Ladyſhip?
I was in hope to day we ſhould have ſeen you
A joyful Bride.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Ah Madam, 'twas my folly
To dream of ſuch a thing; 'tis that has brought me
To all this ſorrow, and undone me quite.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: I hope not ſo. But, Madam, I confeſſe,
The marriage could have done you little good;
One of your years, and then a man ſo old.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Oh do not mention it; I am juſtly puniſh'd.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Pardon me, Madam, I muſt make ſo bold
As leave you for a while. Come Mr. Barnet,
Shall we goe ſee the party? I wait you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: My ſorrow will not leave me. But, alas!
'Tis a deſerved puniſhment I ſuffer
For my unjuſt oppreſſions; I detain'd
Scudmore's eſtate injuriouſly, and had
No conſcience to reſtore what was not mine:
And now all's tane away; what then I would nor,
I cannot now performe, though I deſire.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Feare not, Artemia, there ſhall no meanes
Be left untry'd to ſave the Gentleman.
I did approve thy choice, and ſtill will do,
If fortune will conſent. My Lady Covet,
Are you ſad ſtill?

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Never had any woman
A greater cauſe of ſorrow, Mr. Freeman,
For I proteſt it does not trouble me
So much, that by this cheat I loſe the power
Of my eſtate, as that I loſe all meanes
Of charity, or reſtitution,
To any perſon whom I wrong'd before.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Why then you make a true and perfect uſe
Of ſuch a croſſe, and may hereafter take
True comfort from it.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: If my conſcience
Were ſatisfi'd, I could forſake the reſt.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: My Cozen I perceive has made more haſt
Hither then I; but I have ſeen a pageant
That in the ſaddeſt time would make one laugh.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: What, prethee?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I have ſeen you neighbour Earthworm
In ſuch a mood as you would wonder at,
And all that ever knew him heretofore.
He is inveighing 'gainſt Sir Argent Scrape
For being ſo baſely covetous, as thus
For hope of lucre to betray his kinſman;
A thing that he himſelf would ſcorne as much,
He does proteſt, as can be.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: I have known
It otherwiſe; what may not come to paſſe
When Earthworm is a foe to avarice?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: But he they ſay has made it good in deedes.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: He has been ſo exceeding bountiful
Now to our poore, and vowes to be ſo ſtill,
That we may well beleeve he is quite chang'd,
And ſtrives to make amends for what is paſt.
He has they ſay a brave and vertuous ſonne
Lately come home, that has been cauſe of all.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: It well may be; I know yong Theodore;
Uncle, he is of ſtrange abilities,
And to convert his father was an act
Worthy of him.

div.stage: Enter ſervant, and Sir Argent in his chaire.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Madam, Sir Argent Scrape would take his leave
Of you.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: When it pleaſe him.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Get me my litter
Ready preſently, I will be gone, Madam,
I now am come to give you loving thanks
For my good cheare, and ſo bid you farewel:
But let me tell you this before we part,
Things might have been carryed another way
For your own good; but you may thank your ſelf
For what has happen'd now.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: If you ſuppoſe
It had been for my good to marry you,
You are deceiv'd, for that in my eſteem
(Though once I was ſo fooliſh to give way
To that ridiculous motion) had brought with it
As great a miſery as that which now
Is fall'n upon me

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: How, as great a miſery
As to be begger'd?

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Yes Sir, Ile aſſure you
I am of that opinion, and ſtill ſhall be:
But know, Sir Argent, though I now want power
To give you that which you ſtill gap'd for, wealth,
I can be charitable, and beſtow
Somewhat upon you that is better farre.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Better then wealth? what's that?

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Honeſt counſel:
Let my calamitie admoniſh you
To make a better uſe of your large wealth,
While you may call it yours: things may be chang'd:
For know, that hand that has afflicted me,
Can fin out you: you do not ſtand above it.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: I hope I ſhall know how to keepe mine own.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I do begin to pity the poore Lady.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: This has wrought goodneſs in her. Who are theſe?

div.l: My neighbour Earthworm? Lord! how he is chang'd.

sp.speaker: Earth.
sp.l: 'Twas baſely done, and like a covetous wretch,
Ile tell him to his face: what care I for him?
I have a purſe, as well as he.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Earth.
sp.l: Betray a kinſmans life to purchaſe wealth?
Oh deteſtable!

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Oh miraculous change!
Do you not heare him Uncle?

sp.speaker: Earth.
sp.l: Mr. Freeman,
Happily met.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Sir I am glad to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Earth.
sp.l: I have been long your neighbour Sir, but liv'd
In such a faſhion as I muſt indeavour
To make a mends hereafter for, and ſtrive
To recempence with better neighbourhood.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: It joyes me much to ſee this change in you.

sp.speaker: Earth.
sp.l: Pardon my boldneſs, Madam, that I make
This intruſion.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Y'are welcome, Mr. Earthworm.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Let me be bold then, noble Theodore,
To claime our old acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I ſhall think it
My honour, worthy Sir, to hold that name.

sp.speaker: Earth.
sp.l: Is that Sir Argent Scrape in the chair yonder?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Earth.
sp.l: Oh fy upon him: but ſoft,
He will be told on't now.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Ha! Eugeny,
Why have they brought him hither?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I am come:
Me thinks theſe looks of mine, inhumane wretch,
Though I were ſilent, ſhould have power to pierce
That treacherous breaſt, and wound thy conſcience
Though it be hard, and ſenſeleſs, as the idol
Which thou ador'ſt, thy gold.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Is this to me,
Kinſman, you ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Kinſman? do not wrong
That honeſt name, with thy unhallowed lips.
To finde a name for thee, and thy ſoule guilt,
Has ſo farre pos'd me, as I cannot make
Choice of a language fit, to tell thee of it:
Treacherous bloody man, that haſt betray'd
And ſold my life to thy baſe avarice.

sp.speaker: Arg.
sp.l: Who, I betray you?

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Yes, can you deny it?

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Ile witneſs it againſt him, if he do.
'Twas his intent I know.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: And ſo do I,
I overheard his counſels.

sp.speaker: Earth.
sp.l: Out upon him,
Unworthy man.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I could e'ene laugh to heare
Old Earthworm childe.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: But think upon the deed,
Think on your own decrepid age, and know,
That day by natures poſſibilitie
Cannot be farre from hence, when you muſt leave
Thoſe wealthy hoords that you ſo baſely lov'd,
And c • rry nothing with thee, but the guilt
Of impious getting; then if you would glve
To pious uſes what you cannot keep,
Think what a wretched Charity it is;
And know, this Act ſhall leave a greater ſtain
On your deteſted memory, then all
Thoſe ſeeming deeds of Charity can have
A power to waſh away; when men ſhall ſay,
In the next age, This goodly Hoſpital,
This houſe of Alms, thi • School, though ſeeming fair,
Was the foul iſſue of a curſed murther,
And took foundation in a Kinſmans Blood.
The priviledge that rich men have in evil,
Is, that they go unpuniſh'd to the Devil.

sp.speaker: Arg
sp.l: Oh! I could wiſh the deed undone again:
Ah me! What means are left to help it now?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Sure the old man begins to melt indeed.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Now let me turn to you, my truer Friends,
And take my laſt farewell.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: My noble Chaplain,
What pranks comes he to play now? I had thought
His buſineſs had been done.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: Health to you Madam.

sp.speaker: Cov
sp.l: How can you wiſh me health, that have ſo labour'd
To ruine me in all things?

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: No, good Madam,
'Twas not your ruine, but your good I ſought.
Nor was it to deprive you of your means,
But onely rectifie your conſcience.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Another fetch; this may be worth
The hearing.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: Madam, you convey'd away
To three good Honeſt men, your whole Eſtate.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: The have not prov'd ſo honeſt; I had thought
I might have truſted them.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: Then give me hearing:
They by the vertue of that Deed poſſeſt,
Have back again convey'd it all to you.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: Madam, 'twas done before good Witneſſes,
Of which your Steward here, was one.

sp.speaker: Truſt.
sp.l: Moſt true.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: And all the other are well known to you;
Here is the Deed.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Let me peruſe it Madam.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Good Mr Freeman do.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: What plot is this?

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: One Mannor onely they except from hence,
Which they ſuppo • e you did unjuſtly hold
From the crue Heir; his name was Scudmore, Madam,

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: I do confeſs I did unjuſtly hold it,
And ſince have grieved much, that while I might,
I made not reſtitution.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: He was poor,
And by the Law could not recover it,
Therefore this means was taken; by this Deed
They have convey'd it hither, where it ought
Of right to be: are you content with this?
And all the reſt of your Eſtate is yours.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Madam, the Deed is good.

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: For that Eſtate which juſtly is paſs'd over
To Scudmores Heir, I am ſo well content,
As that, before theſe Gentlemen, I promiſe
To pay him back all the Arrearages
Of whatſoever profits I have made.

sp.speaker: Fruit.
sp.l: I thank your Ladyſhip; Now know your Chaplain
That wanted Orders,

sp.speaker: Cov.
sp.l: Mr. Scudmore living! diſcovers himſelf.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: My Friend, how could'ſt thou keep conceal'd ſo long
From me?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Excuſe it, noble Euphues.

sp.speaker: Arte.
sp.l: Oh happineſs! beyond what could be hop'd!
My Eugeny is ſafe, and all his griefs
At quiet now.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: Is this a viſion,
A meer fantaſtick ſhew? or do I ſee
Scudmore himſelf alive? then let me beg
Pardon from him.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Long ago 'twas granted;
Thy love I now ſhall ſeek: but though a while
For theſe my ends I have conceal'd my ſelf,
I ever meant to ſecure thee from danger.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: What ſtrange unlook'd for happineſs this day
Has brought forth with it!

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: To tell you by what means
I was moſt ſtrangely cur'd, and found a way
How to conceal my life, will be too long
Now to diſcourſe of here, I will anon
Relare at large; but one thing much has griev'd me,
That my too long concealment has been cauſe
Of ſo much ſorrow to my conſtant Love,
The fair Matilda. Sir, ſhe is your Neece,
Let me intreat my pardon, next to her,
From you.

sp.speaker: Earthw.
sp.l: You have it: Go, good Theodore,
And bring her hither, but prepare her firſt:
Too ſudden apprehenſion of a joy
Is ſometimes fatal.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I'll about it gladly.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Dear Cozen Eugeny, if I yet may be
Thought worthy of that name, pardon my crime,
And my whole life, how ſhort ſoere it be,
Shall teſtifie my love to be unfained.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: I do forgive you freely Now to you
Grave Sir, in whoſe rich bounty it muſt lie,
To make me happy, in conferring on me
So bright a Jewel as Artemia,
'Tis your conſent I beg.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: You have it freely;
Her heart I know, ſhe gave you long ago,
And here I give her hand.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: A richer gift
Then any Monarch of the world can give.
Bleſt happyneſs! gently my joyes diſtil,
I eſt you do break the veſſel you ſhould fill.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Here comes another couple to make up
The dayes feſtivitie, Joy to you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Thanks noble Euphues.

sp.speaker: Dot.
sp.l: We have ty'd the knot
That cannot be undone: this Gentleman
Is witneſs of it.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.l: Yes, I ſaw it finiſht.

sp.speaker: Whim.
sp.l: Mrs. Artemia, as I ſuppoſe,
I may pronounce as much to you.

sp.speaker: Art.
sp.l: You may
As much as I ſhall wiſh your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: Here comes the deareſt object of my ſoule,
In whom too much I ſee my cruelty,
And chide my ſelf; Oh pardon me, deare Love,
That I too long a time have tyranniz'd
Over thy conſtant ſorrow.

sp.speaker: Mat.
sp.l: Deareſt Scudmore,
But that my worthy Cozen has prepar'd
My heart for this, I ſhould not have believ'd
My flattering eyes.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.l: To know brave Theodore,
Next to enjoying thee, was my ambition;
Which now affinity hath bleſt me with.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: His friendſhip, worthy Scudmore, is a treaſure.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: I ſhall endeavour to deſerve your loves.

sp.speaker: Earth.
sp.l: Come, leave your complements, at all hands now,
And hear an old man ſpeak; I muſt entreat
This favour from all this noble company,
Eſpecially from you good Mr. Freeman,
Although this be your Daughters wedding day,
That you would all be pleas'd to be my Gueſts,
And keep with me your marriage-feſtivals.
Grant my requeſt.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: 'Tis granted, Sir, from me.

sp.speaker: Eug.
sp.l: And ſo I think from all the company.

sp.speaker: Earth.
sp.l: Then let's be merry, Earthworme's jovial now,
And that's as much as he deſires from you.

div.head: An advertiſement of Books worth buying to be ſold by S. Speed at the Printing-Preſsin Paul's Church-Yard.
div.p:
MR. Caryl his Expoſition with practical obſervations, on the fifteenth, ſixteenth
ſeventeeth Chapters of the Book of Iob. In Qarto.
The Valley of Viſion, being twenty one Sermons, delivered by that Learned and Reverend Divine, Richard Holſworth, Doctor in Divinity. In Quarto.
Mr. Greenhil his Expoſition on the firſt nineteen Chapters of the Prophet Ezekiel, with uſeful obſervations thereupon. In Quarto.
The VVorks of Mr. Nicholas Luckyer, M. A digeſted into one Volume. In Quarto.
Goſpel Liberty, by Mr. Walter Cradock. In Quarto.
Paracelſus of Metals and Minerals. In Octav.
The Life of Guzman the Rogue, a piece of moſt are contexture, in Octa.
Mr. Iohn Simpſon O juſtification. In 8.
Mr. Ainſworths Communion of ſaints. In 8.
—Arrow againſt Idolatrie. In 8.
Dr. Sadlers Enchiridion of the art of Phyſick. In 8.
The firſt Exhortation of H. N. to his children, and to the family of love. Likewiſe H. N. on the Beatitudes, and the ſeaven deadly ſins. In 8.
Mrs. Sarah Wights wonderful and comfortable letter to a friend. In 8.
A Patterne of Catechiſtical Doctrine, by the reverend Father in God, Lancelot Andrews, Lord Biſhop of Wincheſter. In 12.
The New Teſtament in Welch. In 12.
Mr. Samuel Richardſons Divine conſolations. In 12.
Several Romanes, Poems and Playes.

With variety of Bookes
Aſtrological.
Aſtronomical.
Mathematical.
Likewiſe,
There will be ſuddenly extant an excellent work, entituled Aſtrological inſtitutions, written in Latine by Guido Bonatus, and tranſlated into Engliſh by a skilful Student. In 8.
